results.title: Weekly review. Ep. 382. This is the weather office
results.creator_credit: Stanhope Andrews, New Zealand National Film Unit and J.M.D. Hardwick
results.brief_description: The work of the weather office of New Zealand where, with the assistance of 120 reporting stations in New Zealand and on surrounding islands and reports from ships at sea, meteorological information is collated and from it the weather forecast is given.

results.title: Weekly review. 187th week. The Pilchard fishermen
results.brief_description: The pilchard fishermen in New Zealand’s Marlborough Sound haul their nets by night. At dawn carrier pigeons fly from the boats to the canning factory with reports of the size of the catch, so that when the boats come in all is ready for processing the fish.

results.title: Weekend Magazine: William Strutt
results.brief_description: Against the background of a Parliament House launching of Marjorie Tipping’s book “Victoria the Golden”, this film focuses on the watercolors of William Strutt, painted during the gold rush period in Victoria. They depict scenes of watercarters, the goldfields, people on their way to the diggings, women doing traditional men’s work in Melbourne when the men left to search for gold, the opening of the Legislative Council and the departure of the Burke and Wills expedition from Melbourne. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Weekend magazine: kite flying festival
results.brief_description: The 1983 Singapore International Kite Festival provided a venue for kite enthusiasts from all over the world. This film features some of the entries, including traditional eastern kites and more innovative designs such as the world’s largest kite which required a huge army truck as an anchor. Also takes a brief historical look at the kite and people’s fascination with it.

results.title: Weekend Magazine: free music
results.creator_credit: Rex Clayton and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: Explains Percy Grainger’s ideas about free music and shows the machine he had made with the help of Bernard Cross. The machine is very like a synthesizer and was meant to play Grainger’s music, which proved an impossible task for people. A Melbourne Conservatorium expert was the first person to transcribe the music on graphs on to tape, and in Bernard Cross’s presence it was played for the first time publicly.

results.title: Weekend at Cradle Mountain
results.creator_credit: C Wolnizer, Tasmanian Council for Children's Films and Television, Children's Films and Television, Island Film Services and W. H. Perkins
results.brief_description: Shows the children of a family spending a weekend at the chalet in Cradle Mountain Reserve going on two long walks past the mountain lakes, life at the chalet, the chalet keeper and the ranger, and their native pets. Cast: Margaret, Marcus and Duncan. Commentary by Nan Chauncey.

results.title: Wednesdays [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Jeremy Stanford
results.brief_description: Shelly (Josephine Byrnes) awakens one Wednesday morning and slowly descends down the stairs in her pajamas. As the morning progresses the viewer learns of love found, lost, jealousy, suspicion and a murder as she retraces the steps of how she discovered her partner, John’s (Greg Stone) infidelity - or does she?

results.title: Wednesday in April
results.brief_description: In image and sound, the film describes an average day as it is lived across the varied scene of the continent of America. Cowboy, farmer or urban worker, every citizen is free to weave his own unique pattern into the infinite, multi-colored American tapestry. Narrated by Lee Marvin.

results.title: Wedgwood
results.creator_credit: Clifford Parris, World Wide and Ray Townsend
results.brief_description: An insight into the world of Wedgwood - one of the most celebrated pottery manufacturers in the world. Bernard Price talks about the extraordinary man Joshua I, who founded the company in 1759, and then discusses Wedgwood designs, both antique and modern, with a number of people both inside and outside the Wedgwood organisation.

results.title: Wedding at York
results.brief_description: The wedding of HRH the Duke of Kent and Miss Katherine Worsley at York Minster. As the bride leavers her home, members of the Royal Family assemble at the great cathedral. The arrival of Her Majesty the Queen with Prince Philip and Prince Charles is followed by the ceremony at which Dr Ramsey, then Archbishop of York, officiated. The wedding over, the bride and her husband leave the cathedral to the cheers of waiting crowds.
